title: Qantas fined $90 million for illegally sacking staff
text:
Australia's largest airline has been ordered to pay a landmark penalty of $90 million for what has been dubbed the largest case of illegal sackings in the country's history.

Qantas outsourced more than 1800 baggage handlers, cleaners and ground staff in 2020, in a move the Federal Court ruled was designed to curb union bargaining power in wage negotiations.

The embattled airline's appeal to the High Court was unsuccessful, paving the way for the penalty to be awarded on Monday.

Qantas will cop a heavy fine today for illegally sacking more than 1800 workers. (Wolter Peeters/SMH)

The Transport Workers Union sought the maximum penalty of $121 million, while Qantas urged Justice Michael Lee to impose a "mid-range" penalty between $40 million and $80 million.

The Federal Court judge cited the "sheer scale of the contraventions, being the largest of their type" as a reason to impose a penalty that would deter other businesses from similar conduct.

He ordered Qantas to pay $90 million in penalties, $50 million of which is to be paid directly to the union that brought the proceedings and highlighted the illegal conduct.

"To deprive someone of work illegally is to deprive someone of an aspect of their human dignity, and this is not assuaged simply by expressions of regret," Justice Lee said.

Former Qantas chief executive Alan Joyce. (Janie Barrett)

He was scathing about the embattled airline's conduct after the outsourcing, pointing to efforts to place a "less than candid" picture of the outsourcing decision before the court.

He noted Qantas had apologised publicly but then had attempted to deny any compensation payments to the affected workers.

Qantas will have to pay the hefty bill on top of a $120 million compensation payment it has made to the affected ground staff for their economic loss, pain and suffering following the outsourcing.

However, Justice Lee said he didn't have enough evidence to be convinced those payments would be made.

The court was told the scandal-plagued airline began to finally accept responsibility for its actions in 2023, Justice Lee noted, which coincided with the departure of former CEO Alan Joyce.

The courtroom was packed with union members and representatives, who hugged and exchanged smiles after Justice Lee handed down his decision.

It comes after Qantas also sold tickets to cancelled flights for several years, triggering more legal turmoil and a $100 million fine after it was sued by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission.

title: Stuntman set on fire for Pink Floyd album cover dies aged 88
text:
Hollywood stuntman Ronnie Rondell Jr, best known for being photographed engulfed in flames for Pink Floyd's Wish You Were Here album, has died at the age of 88.

A care home in the US state of Missouri announced his death on August 12.

Rondell performed in numerous films and TV shows, including Star Trek, The Matrix Reloaded and Charlie's Angels.

In 1970 he co-founded the Stunts Unlimited talent agency to supply stunt performers for Hollywood films.

In a post on the Stunts Unlimited Facebook page, the company said: "Our hearts are heavy with the loss of the last of Stunts Unlimited's 3 esteemed founding fathers, Ronnie Rondell.

"In a class all his own, Ronnie was a generous mentor whose talents set the bar for every aspiring stunt person. He was deeply respected, admired and loved. Ronnie was not just a legend, he was legendary and will be deeply missed."

Iconic Pink Floyd shot took multiple takes

Ronnie Rondell (right) on the Wish You Were Here album cover. (Getty Images: Rahman Hassani/SOPA Images/LightRocket)

Rondell was best known for posing as the businessman on fire for Pink Floyd's 1975 album cover Wish You Were Here.

His suit and hair were covered in flame-retardant gel to save him from injury.

The photographer who took the iconic shot, Aubrey Powell, later told The Guardian that on the 15th take a gust of wind blew the flames into Rondell's face, burning off part of his moustache.

Wish You Were Here topped the album charts in Australia, the US and the UK, and in 2023 ranked 264th on Rolling Stone magazine's list of 500 greatest albums.

title: Sweet moment in WA's Pilbara as couple engaged at inaugural rodeo
text:
Emma Holten was wondering where her partner Paul Irwin was when she was announced the winner of a prize at the Roebourne Rodeo in Western Australia's Pilbara region.

Emma was worried Paul would miss her big moment.

Little did she know, it was all part of a bigger plan.

"Just before my name was announced, Paul had to leave," Emma said.

"My name got called out as the winner and my first thought was, 'Oh, Paul's not going to see me win my prize.'"

Heart on his sleeve, dust on his knees

When Emma went up to the announcers to claim her prize, she turned around and — to her surprise — found Paul bended on one knee, ring in hand.

"That moment when I turned around and saw Paul on one knee with the ring, it was amazing," she said.

" It was a bit of a blur after that. I sort of lost sight of everyone else and it was just … me and Paul. "

Paul Irwin says he was confident Emma Holten would accept his proposal. (ABC Pilbara: Kimberley Putland)

When asked if he was nervous that Emma would say no in front of thousands, Paul said he had full faith.

"I didn't have [any] doubts that she was going to say no," he said.

"I was pretty confident it was going to be, 'Yes.'

"I thought I would do it on our fourth-year anniversary [because] it'd save remembering so many different dates."

The first Roebourne Rodeo drew a crowd of thousands. (ABC Pilbara: Kimberley Putland)

A rodeo of firsts

Paul said it was the first rodeo he had been to.

"I didn't even know if you were allowed to do it or not, or if it was going to work," he said.

Roebourne Rodeo's arena, where Paul Irwin asked Emma Holten to marry him. (ABC Pilbara: Kimberley Putland)

Rodeo co-founder Tui Magner said she was happy the couple could have their special moment at the first edition of the Roebourne Rodeo.

Ms Magner connected Paul with the event's announcers and DJ to organise the finer details, like playing Emma's favourite song, Luke Combs's Beautiful Crazy, when he proposed.

"They got on board straight away," she said.

"There was plenty of firsts at that rodeo, being our first, so it was a really nice touch to add to the mix.

"It was really cool to be asked to do that at our rodeo."

So, will it be a rodeo-themed wedding for the couple?

"[There's] going to be white cowboy boots as part of my wedding outfit," Emma said.

"So on some level there'll be a country theme."

title: Man fixes cars to gift disadvantaged drivers in memory of his son
text:
Wimmera man Gavin "Bear" Hynam lost his eldest son, Preston, in an accident just before his 21st birthday in 2008.

After years of grief, Mr Hynam began channelling his passion for mentoring young people in the local community by fixing pre-loved cars and gifting them to disadvantaged youths in and around the regional Victorian town of Horsham.

"I got a little bit of spring back in my step," Mr Hynam said.

As of August this year, the 64-year-old has handed over 19 sets of keys to young locals in need.

Chance at better life

The scheme began in 2017 when Mr Hynam met two refugees who had recently moved to the Wimmera.

He admired how hard the newcomers worked to build a new life in country Victoria and realised they needed a mode of transport.

A mechanic by trade, Mr Hynam decided he would fix two second-hand cars and gift them to his new friends.

Kylie Zanker (left), car recipient Kaitlyn Sommerfield and Gavin Hynam with the fixed-up car. (ABC News: Tamara Clark)

"They're young men and we're helping them out and making them want to, you know, become part of our community," he said.

"I just said [to his family], 'Well, I'm going to give him a car when they get their licence.'"

After gifting a car each to the two young asylum seeker men, Mr Hynam decided to give away a third car to a South American migrant.

Mr Hynam said he became addicted to the joy of seeing good, hard-working people get a chance at a better life.

Gifting cars to students in need

Fifteen years ago, Mr Hynam began working in the Transport Accident Commission's (TAC) L2P program.

L2P is a Victorian program to help learner drivers get their 120 hours of driving practice, and ultimately, their licence.

Soon after his induction, Mr Hynam realised he could offer Wimmera youth more than just driving advice.

"I said to my family, I'm going to give away two cars this year to the young people that I'm teaching," Mr Hynam said.

Gavin Hynam says it's hard to say goodbye to his students, including Chelsea Robinson, once they graduate. (ABC News: Tamara Clark)

'I used to walk everywhere'

Chelsea Robinson is an 18-year-old high school student working towards a career in alcohol and drug counselling.

She lost her relationship with her parents when she was aged six, and lives with her older brother.

At the start of 2024, social support service Uniting Wimmera engaged Ms Robinson in the L2P program where she met Mr Hynam.

"To be in that program and have an instructor like Bear, it was a great experience and it was definitely something that I looked forward to every Sunday morning," Ms Robinson said.

"It was more so the things that we spoke about. We connected through a lot of different ways."

Gavin Hynam gives Chelsea Robinson keys to the car they've been driving. (ABC News: Tamara Clark)

At the end of their lessons, Ms Robinson successfully completed her licence test, and Mr Hynam gifted her the keys to the car they'd been driving.

"It felt amazing," she said.

"Without Bear's help, I wouldn't have been able to get my licence or be able to have the car that I do now, so I'm very grateful.

"I used to walk everywhere and now I don't have to, so it's definitely a very big privilege."

Young mum gains freedom

Horsham woman Kaitlyn Sommerfield is a 23-year-old mother to four-year-old Harper.

Before Mr Hynam gave Ms Sommerfield her first car, she had to walk her special-needs daughter to appointments.

Kaitlyn Sommerfield holds the keys to her first car, donated by Gavin Hynam. (ABC News: Tamara Clark)

"I needed some help getting [a] car because my daughter might be going to kinder on another side of Horsham," Ms Sommerfield said.

" We just [didn't] go out as much because you know, it's hard to get around. "

Harper's NDIS support coordinator at Grampians Community Health and Yarriambiack Shire Council Mayor Kylie Zanker called Mr Hynam for help.

"I could hear the distress [in] Kaitlyn, like, 'How do I get my daughter to those OT appointments, to speech, to physio?' to all of the things that she needs," Ms Zanker said.

Kylie Zanker says she is overwhelmed by Gavin Hynam's generosity. (ABC News: Tamara Clark)

'Amazing community spirit'

Coincidentally, less than an hour before Ms Zanker's call, Mr Hynam had purchased an elderly community member's car for about $2,500.

He immediately began preparing the vehicle for Ms Sommerfield.

"He's just the most amazing human. He truly is. He's so humble," Ms Zanker said.

"Bear just has the biggest heart and the most amazing community spirit … it obviously helps Kaitlyn, but it also affects her daughter, Harper.

" So, it's not one life that Bear's touched, it's two. "

Gavin Hynam tells Kylie Zanker and Kaitlyn Sommerfield: "Part of this must have come from Preston, my son." (ABC News: Tamara Clark)

Mr Hynam has spent about $20,000 of his own money on the scheme.

The community also raised about $8,000 for him, which lasted a couple of years.

Chelsea Robinson leaving Gavin Hynam's garage in the car he gifted her. (ABC News: Tamara Clark)

Mr Hynam said he had been forced to keep using his own money to fund the scheme — even though it's running low.

"I've never known a person to give so selflessly, whether it's L2P driving, or with youth and teaching them, you know, mechanical skills, gifting cars," Ms Zanker said.

"I know of four people who've gotten to university and two people who've gotten jobs, and are able to hold down employment because of Bear's generosity."

Mr Hynam says he is driven by the memory of his son.

"Part of this must have come from Preston, my son, who's no longer with us," he said.

title: 'Wrong kind of sorry': Qantas fined $90 million penalty for illegally outsourcing jobs
text:
Airline giant Qantas will face a $90 million penalty over its decision to illegally outsource more than 1,800 ground handling jobs during the COVID pandemic.

Federal Court Justice Michael Lee said on Monday the penalty must "bear some resemblance" to the maximum $121 million — and should be no less than $90 million, which is 75 per cent of the maximum.

He said $50 million of the penalty should be paid to the Transport Workers Union (TWU).

How the remaining $40 million balance will be paid - and whether it will go to workers - will be decided at a later hearing.

It follows a 2020 decision by Qantas to outsource its ground handling workforce, which the Federal Court later found to be illegal.

The TWU had called for the airline to be fined a maximum of $121 million, in addition to the $120 million in compensation it's required to pay the affected employees.

Qantas had argued the court instead impose a "mid-range" penalty between $40 million and $80 million.

Justice Lee said Qantas had shown the "wrong kind of sorry", whereby it worried more about the impact on the company rather than the impact the case had on the illegally sacked workers.

He noted that that the airline's chief people officer, Catherine Walsh, apologised for the company's behaviour during hearings, but "it seemed to be obvious that the person who could give the most direct and compelling evidence of corporate change and contrition" was CEO Vanessa Hudson.

Qantas CEO Vanessa Hudson has apologised to sacked workers but only after Qantas mounted legal action and lost. (AAP: Bianca De Marchi)

"I accept that Miss Walsh is a sincere and competent professional who will do her personal best to prevent a re-occurrence of contravening conduct. As the person responsible for industrial relations, she now reports directly to the CEO," Justice Lee said.

"But given the extent of the cultural problem revealed by this case, I would have been much more persuaded (about) the genuineness of contrition if her evidence had been supplemented by a member of senior management who was present when the proposal was socialised and evaluated, and explained why things went so wrong, how they had been converted in new ways of doing things, and how lessons have been learnt.

"Time will only tell whether the undoubted good intentions of Miss Walsh will prevail. The scope of the task … not to be underestimated.

"The strategy adopted by Qantas at the compensation hearing rather suggested an industrial relations culture that has very deep, very deep roots. Despite high level representations of change following the departure of some key personnel in 2023."

Justice Lee said while Qantas ended up later expressing "genuine regrets", that "this more likely reflects the damage this case has done at the company rather than unique remorse for the damage done to the affected workers".

He said the airline "resisted until it could resist no more".

"And, as on multiple occasions prior to this hearing, sought to explain the way as representing no moral or ethical failure."

Record penalty shows 'courts won't tolerate blatant attacks on workers' rights'

Maurice Blackburn Lawyers principal Josh Bornstein said the penalty is the biggest ever ordered by a court for violations of industrial relations laws in Australian history, and meant corporate Australia was on notice that courts "would not tolerate blatant attacks on workers' rights".

"This record-breaking penalty reflects the monumental scale of Qantas's wrongdoing and the court's concern that Qantas and the business community need to understand that calculated, mass violations of workplace laws may result in severe financial punishment," Mr Bornstein said.

Michael Kaine and Josh Bornstein outside the court. (ABC News: John Gunn)

He said Qantas, under former CEO Alan Joyce's leadership, "seized the opportunity presented by the COVID pandemic to realise its long-held aim — to rid its operations of the TWU and its members working as baggage handlers and ground staff".

"This was a carefully planned and executed union-busting operation," Mr Bornstein said.

"Qantas worked for months on its plan to try and avoid an adverse outcome in a legal challenge. Qantas tried to hide the involvement of Alan Joyce in the plan. The plan fell apart once Qantas had to hand over documents and its executives were cross examined in the Federal Court."

He said the payment of the penalty to the TWU reflects the risks it took to pursue the case on behalf of its members and other employees of Qantas, and "should encourage others to pursue compliance with industrial relations laws".

TWU national secretary Michael Kaine said in 2020 more than 1,800 Qantas workers took on a "huge and audacious battle" against the airline.

"Today's decision is a final win for both those workers and the tens of thousands of other TWU members who backed them every step of the way," he said.

"These were committed Qantas workers who had done nothing wrong and had loyally served this company, in many cases for decades.

" They [Qantas workers] weren't just sacked, they were told by Qantas that they were delusional for questioning it. This ruthless, self-interested and illegal calculation to kick them to the curb has rightfully merited the largest ever penalty of its kind. "

He said the $90 million penalty was a "message to corporate Australia that workers will stand up for what's right".

Labor senator Tony Sheldon said the case "now marks three major legal defeats for Qantas in recent years — a deeply damning pattern".

"The courts have found it unlawfully stood down a union health and safety rep for raising COVID concerns, illegally sacked its ground crew, and now must be penalised for breaching the Fair Work Act," Senator Sheldon noted.

In May 2024, Qantas faced a $100 million penalty for misleading customers by selling tickets to flights that had already been cancelled. The airline was sued by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC).

In November 2023, Qantas was found guilty of illegally standing down worker Theo Seremetidis who had raised concerns about COVID-19 risk to staff who were cleaning aircraft arriving from China in the early phases of the pandemic.

title: Wallabies braced for 'punch in the face' from Springboks
text:
Under no illusions, Australia are bracing for some fierce backlash from South Africa in the two sides' return Rugby Championship stoush in Cape Town.

While delighted with his side's resilience and growing belief shown in Saturday's colossal comeback win over the back-to-back world champions in Johannesburg, Wallabies coach Joe Schmidt is not getting carried away.

He believes the Springboks took their foot off the pedal after motoring to a 22-0 lead inside 18 minutes before succumbing to the Wallabies at Ellis Park for the first time since 1963.

"I've coached enough teams because I'm really old," the 60-year-old Kiwi said.

"I've had teams who got a very, very rapid start. It can sometimes just cause a bit of a lapse in effort and concentration. I think they just gave us a little bit of belief.

"As well as [man of the match] Fraser [McReight] did and the other players did, we were probably a little bit lucky because Pieter-Steph [du Toit] at one stage just went to pick and go and he just knocked it on."

Dylan Pietsch scores at Ellis Park. (AP: Frans Lombard)

Schmidt said it was unlikely the Springboks would repeat such mistakes next weekend.

"There were a couple of uncharacteristic errors from the Springboks where, I think next week, if they pick and go there, he [du Toit] is such a powerful, athletic man, he will be a handful," he said.

"It was probably a mix of us and a little bit of inaccuracy from the Springboks because when they were accurate, you saw that first 20 minutes.

"I saw wave after wave and even that very first drive was impressive.

"We probably got a little bit lucky, even when Andre [Esterhuizen] went down the left-hand touch a couple of times.

"One of the times, [Wallaby] Tom Wright went 70 metres and scored at the other end."

Schmidt says the Wallabies cannot expect a repeat of the Springboks' second-half lapse when the two teams meet again next Sunday morning (AEST).

"We know that pressure is coming," he said.

"I've coached against the Boks with a few other international teams and come out second.

"I know whether they're favourites or not, they're a heck of a team."

The Wallabies bench celebrates during the Ellis Park comeback. (Getty Images: Gallo Images/Sydney Seshibedi)

Lock Will Skelton and veteran flyhalf James O'Connor revealed the Wallabies quietly celebrated while also reviewing the epic 38-22 triumph on laptops, knowing full well the Boks would likely respond in ruthless fashion.

"A lot of the boys are already onto next week. The boys are reviewing, everyone's clipping stuff," Skelton said.

"We know what's going to come. They're going to try and punch you in the face this week.

"So we're going to have to have a good week of preparation again and really fight until the end."

After playing a lead role in his first Test since 2022, 35-year-old O'Connor said the Wallabies "enjoyed each other's company" but were not getting carried away.

"That's the thing about rugby — you're already on to next week. I know my mind went there," he said.

"I thought straight away, 'What are they going to be coming with — 6-2 bench, back to basics, bomb squad, aerial contest?

"They're going to meet us in the trenches there, so I'm already thinking about what's coming and then just focusing on recovery."

With winger Dylan Pietsch (broken jaw), utility back Ben Donaldson (abductor muscle) and prop James Slipper (concussion) all returning home, Filipo Daugunu, Hamish Stewart and Rhys van Nek will fly to South Africa to join the Wallabies.

AAP

title: From washed out to weathering on, stock losses cut deep in outback Qld
text:
It took just days for a lifetime of work to wash away as swollen rivers and creeks became an inland ocean across outback Queensland.

Readers are advised this story contains distressing content.

In March and April, widespread flooding tore through an area twice the size of Victoria, leaving devastation in its wake.

Graziers like Brendan Murray, from Eromanga, were left questioning their future in the industry they dedicated their lives to.

Brendan Murray's Eromanga property was hit with large rainfall totals and widespread flooding in March 2025. (ABC Landline: Cameron Lang)

"We're the custodians of our stock," Mr Murray said.

" That's our job to keep them safe and well. "

For days, helicopters dropped Mr Murray and his son Henry into paddocks across his property Tallyabra, and they walked stock from flooded areas to higher ground.

Brendan Murray lost two thirds of his merino sheep flock. (Supplied: Henry Murray)

He estimates they lost 6,000 merino sheep in full wool.

"A lot of the sheep … just couldn't live it out neck deep in water for five days," he said.

Fifty-six kilometres of the Murrays' exclusion fencing was severely damaged or washed away as well as internal fencing.

It took just over a month to repair or replace damaged fencing at Tallyabra after the floods. (ABC Landline: Cameron Lang)

"They were all on the ground," he said.

"From one end of the paddock to the other."

In 16 weeks, the Murrays worked as quickly as they could to rebuild fences for agistment stock.

"We needed cash flow," he said.

"We have to have stock on."

While the landscape is recovering, some areas have major erosion and scarring. (ABC Landline: Cameron Lang)

Stock are now back grazing in the scarred paddocks and Mr Murray is focusing on the positives.

"We have heaps of feed," he said.

" I would prefer it to be our missing 6,000 sheep munching on grass … but there's positives in it. "

Tallyabra Station received 520 millimetres of rain in just eight days, more than double the average yearly total. (ABC Landline: Cameron Lang)

Losses 'cut deep'

South-west of Eromanga, at Nockatunga Station, grazier Linda Evans said her family still didn't know how many head of cattle they had lost.

As water rushed across the large and isolated property, it swept away livestock, horses and native animals.

It was nothing like she'd seen before.

During the peak of the flood, water reached the gate of the Evans's backyard. (Supplied: Michelle Rizzotto)

"The noise of the water roaring was astronomical," Mrs Evans said.

" It was beautiful in a way, but it was terrifying as well. "

The latest figures from the Department of Primary Industries indicate 110,000 head of livestock are confirmed dead and almost as many are still missing or unaccounted for.

The family lost most of their stud horses, as well as a beloved pony that belonged to Mrs Evans's granddaughter.

The Evans family lost 20 of their stud horses, as well as their granddaughter Bella's pony. (ABC Landline: Cameron Lang)

In the days that followed, Mrs Evans busied herself planning the Eromanga Rodeo, an event scheduled for two weeks after the floods hit.

She said it was vital for the community that it went ahead.

"Mental health is probably one of the biggest issues in the bush," she said.

"So being able to provide an event that brought people together and gave them a chance to talk … and realise I'm not the only person in this boat [was so important].

The Eromanga Rodeo was an important community event in the weeks following the floods. (ABC Western Qld: Julia Andre)

" We're here, we're all doing it tough but we've got one another's back. "

For Mrs Evans, witnessing the landscape recover and transform has been healing.

"It's mind blowing," she said.

"It's the reason we do what we do and it's a very special thing to see.

"It's God's country and it's turned it on right now."

Tourism helps community rebuild

It's not just Eromanga that's benefited from community events bringing everyone together.

The tight-knit community of Thargomindah is still in the thick of recovery, but has welcomed much needed tourism back into the area.

Since the town reopened, there have been three major events bringing thousands of tourists into the region.

Hundreds of tourists flocked to Thargomindah in July for the annual Music Muster. (ABC Landline: Cameron Lang)

Bulloo Shire disaster coordinator Tamie Warner said the visitors had helped boost morale in town.

"It gives people something else to focus on," Ms Warner said.

'The flood itself brought people here to see us and see how we're recovering.

"People have been so patient and understanding."

The Bulloo River starts hundreds of kilometres from Thargomindah and runs past towns like Quilpie and Adavale. (ABC Landline: Cameron Lang)

Framed by the Bulloo River, the town has dealt with big floods in the past.

In 1974, the river reached 6.78 metres and became the benchmark for all future floods.

The town's unofficial flood marker, a street sign, shows water reached 8m this year.

A street sign pole at the edge of town became the official flood marker during the floods. (ABC Landline: Cameron Lang)

Months on and Ms Warner said it would take a while for the town to rebuild.

"We know logistically it's a hard place," she said.

" There are only three or four builders and they've got a whole town to rebuild. "

Tamie Warner says locals are resilient. (ABC Landline: Cameron Lang)

But Ms Warner said locals wanted to look to the future, rather than dwell on the past.

"We are an extremely resilient community," she said.

"We've bounced back pretty well … we got our businesses open straight away."

Friends lend a helping hand

Just outside of Thargomindah at Picarilli Station, Gerda and Anthony Glasson were feeling helpless.

Being on a sheep station isolated by floodwaters, there wasn't anything they could do in town, so the pair started the Fridge for a Friend initiative.

It enabled people from anywhere in the country to purchase a fridge or washing machine for a resident.

"All you want to do is help your mates," Mrs Glasson said.

Gerda Glasson wanted to find a way to help her local community during the floods. (ABC Landline: Cameron Lang)

She'd hoped they'd get enough to cover Thargomindah, but there were so many donations they were able to expand to Adavale, Eulo, Hungerford, Jundah, Quilpie and surrounding areas.

Fridges and washing machines were hand delivered for flood-affected communities. (ABC Landline: Cameron Lang/Supplied: Gerda Glasson)

In the end, 96 fridges and 98 washing machines were purchased and delivered across western Queensland.

"It has reminded people of how much others care about you," Mrs Glasson said.

" People look out for each other and there's a lot of good, a lot of good people. "

Watch ABC TV's Landline at 12:30pm AEST on Sunday or stream anytime on ABC iview.

title: Crows star Rankine facing AFL investigation for alleged on-field incident
text:
The AFL's integrity unit is looking into an alleged incident involving Adelaide Crows star Izak Rankine.

Reports on Sunday night suggested Rankine was set to face investigation for allegedly using a homophobic slur during the Crows' game against Collingwood on Saturday.

On Monday, the AFL confirmed it was aware of an alleged matter and that the integrity unit was making enquiries.

An Adelaide spokesperson said the club is "aware of an alleged matter involving one of our players" and confirmed ongoing discussions with the AFL.

Crows captain Jordan Dawson was stopped before training on Monday morning, and said the club would wait for the AFL's verdict.

"It's not ideal but it's obviously in the AFL's hands and we'll let them investigate it and see what happens," Dawson said.

"We'll wait and see but we'll leave it up to the AFL to go through what they have to go through."

If found guilty, Rankine — one of the league-leading Crows' key players — could be at risk of missing the rest of the AFL season.

West Coast's Jack Graham was suspended for four games for use of a homophobic slur in an AFL game earlier this year, while Sydney's Riak Andrew received a five-game ban for the same offence in a VFL match.

Adelaide faces North Melbourne in its final home and away game on Saturday, looking to secure the minor premiership.

After that, the Crows will play at least two finals, and possibly as many as four should they take the long route to the grand final.

title: Kalgoorlie's 'maverick' politician Graeme Campbell dies aged 86
text:
Former member for the West Australian federal seat of Kalgoorlie Graeme Campbell has died, aged 86.

His family posted on social media that he died early Saturday morning at Kalgoorlie Regional Hospital.

Mr Campbell entered politics as a member of the Labor Party after a career as a pastoralist on the remote Nullarbor Plain.

He went on to serve as the member for Kalgoorlie for 18 years, and is remembered by contemporaries as a "colourful" political maverick.

Graeme Campbell worked on stations along the Nullarbor before founding his own. (Supplied: Ainsley Campbell)

From pastoralist to politician

Originally from Oxfordshire in England, Mr Campbell's family emigrated to Australia when he was a child.

He grew up in South Australia and went on to establish Kybo Station, a remote pastoral property on the sparse Nullarbor, with his brother Rod Campbell.

Graeme Campbell (left) and Rod Campbell (third from left) established Kybo Station. (Supplied: Ainsley Campbell)

It was at Kybo he met his wife Michele Lelievre, now Campbell, a French woman who had stopped at the station while on a trip around Australia.

Ms Campbell told the ABC in 2018 she had heard about the Campbell brothers long before heading towards the Nullarbor Plain.

"We made a point of trying to find these chaps, who were apparently a bit different and interesting," she said.

Michele and Graeme Campbell met on a remote sheep station on the Nullarbor in 1972. (Supplied: Michele Campbell)

"I looked at him and thought, 'Definitely, I will stay,' so that was how I met him."

The couple later married and moved to Kalgoorlie, where Mr Campbell worked in mining before turning his attention to politics.

A 'maverick' in politics

Mr Campbell joined the Labor Party in 1980, and was elected as the federal member for Kalgoorlie, a position he held for 17 years and 11 months.

He was known for his pro-mining and anti-immigration views.

In 1988, he challenged then prime minister Paul Keating and crossed the floor in opposition to the government's plan to remove company tax exemptions from gold miners.

Former member for O'Connor, Tony Crook, said the move cemented Mr Campbell as a man of the people.

"What I love most is he was prepared to represent his constituents first and foremost," he said.

Tony Crook says despite holding differing views, Graham Campbell's career in politics inspired him. (ABC Goldfields-Esperance: Nathan Morris)

Mr Campbell was disendorsed by the Labor Party for his outspoken views, and resigned from the party just prior to the 1996 election.

He went on to run as an independent and won, retaining his seat for another two years.

Graeme Campbell was disendorsed by the Labor Party but ran as an independent. (Supplied: Ainsley Campbell)

In a statement to the ABC, Mr Campbell's family said winning the 1996 election as an independent was one of his proudest moments.

"Graeme found special connection to the people of regional Western Australia. "He was deeply honoured to be able to represent his people as the federal member for the seat of Kalgoorlie."

Mr Crook said Mr Campbell's "maverick" style left an incredible legacy in Kalgoorlie politics.

"For Graeme to leave [the Labor Party] and win the federal seat as an independent was huge," he said.

"That was why I crossed the floor as many times as I did [in my own career]."

A change maker until the end

Member for Kalgoorlie Ali Kent agreed Mr Campbell's "maverick" label was warranted.

"He was a very bright and colourful character," she said.

Ali Kent says she first met Graeme Campbell when she moved to Kalgoorlie in 1993. (Supplied: Ali Kent)

"He liked not ever conforming, he always liked to have his own way of doing things."

Ms Kent said Mr Campbell's passion for local issues continued after he left politics.

"Right to the end, he would be at the voting booths … he would always want to have a conversation with you," she said.

Graeme Campbell's family says he continued to make changes where he could. (Supplied: Ainsley Campbell)

A 'straight up and down' bloke

Boulder resident and former chair of the Goldfields Transport Board, Doug Daws, first met Mr Campbell when he was in the Transport Workers Union and the pair came to loggerheads.

"It was probably a very colourful discussion if you could listen to it now," he said.

Mr Daws said despite their disagreements, they went on to become good friends.

"Graham was a great arguer for better things for the Goldfields … and sometimes it wasn't easy for him to do that," he said.

Doug Daws says he first met Graeme Campbell in the early 1980s and they became friends. (ABC Goldfields: Tara De Langrafft)

He remembered fondly when Mr Campbell was meant to be promoting a prospective emu leather and meat farm near Wiluna.

"He came to a meeting with a pair of these [emu leather] shoes on and he told everybody … they were the most uncomfortable shoes he's ever worn in his life," Mr Daws said.

Graeme Campbell was straight up and down and told you how it was, Doug Daws says. (Supplied: Ainsley Campbell)

" That was Graeme, he was very forthright, straight up and down. "

Mr Daws said Mr Campbell would be remembered for his tenacity and passion for the Goldfields.

"He picked up causes and fought for them valiantly, sometimes against overwhelming odds … and his efforts are well recorded in the Hansard of federal parliament," he said.

Graeme Campbell is survived by his wife Michele and two sons, Ainsley and Leyland. (Supplied: Ainsley Campbell)

"He was a very able representative of this district [and] he was a hell of a good bloke.

"He'll be sadly missed."

Mr Campbell leaves behind his wife Michele and two sons, Ainsley and Leyland, who said they were overwhelmed with the outpouring of community sentiment.

"We are honoured and thankful to have had him as our husband and father," the family statement read.

title: 'No industry is safe': Salmon workers respond to halt on fish farm growth
text:
The suspension on the expansion of salmon farms in Tasmania has brought uncertainty to workers, who say the premier has walked back support he guaranteed just weeks earlier.

The Tasmanian government has announced it will launch an independent review of the industry's sustainability and environmental impact, during which there will be a "pause on marine expansion of the industry".

Tasmanian salmon farms expansion plans on pause Photo shows Salmon pens and a boat in waters near a coastline. The Tasmanian government will halt marine expansion of the salmon industry in local waterways while an independent review is ordered.

Salmon farms continue to grapple with the bacterial disease piscirickettsia salmonis, which led to an unprecedented mass mortality event in 2024, with the government currently seeking emergency approval for a new antibiotic to tackle the disease.

Tassal diver Oliver Brewer said he and other workers will not shy away from a review, but "being used as a political tool to appease Greens and Independents" had brought uncertainty for them.

"I have full faith in my industry that it will do the right thing and any review will have a positive outcome," Mr Brewer said.

Marine expansion of the salmon industry in Tasmania will be halted while the independent review takes place. (Supplied: Bob Brown Foundation)

The decision to review the industry and halt its growth comes after a letter Premier Jeremy Rockliff sent to the industry on July 2, which said a re-elected Liberal government would "not introduce moratoriums, bans or arbitrary caps on industry growth and will consider the science and sustainability of any proposal".

The letter also said the Liberals would "not trade the salmon industry in any way, shape or form in order to retain government".

It also follows last week's government announcement to phase out the greyhound industry — which came after the party said it was committed to "support the longevity and sustainability of the racing industry".

Mr Brewer said it was difficult to see broader support for his industry wane over recent years.

"It's always a shame to see that we're ridiculed for the work that we do, and our industry is ridiculed for the work that we do, and it's normally coming from a rather-baseless place where the science is not backing that up," he said.

"And it's always a shame to see that community support, you know, does dwindle sometimes."

Salmon Tasmania chief executive John Whittington said he became aware that Mr Rockliff's position on salmon farming had changed the night before it was announced — calling it "a shameless sellout".

"The premier's words are worthless and clearly no industry is safe," Dr Whittington said.

John Whittington says the "shameless" announcement shows the premier's words are "worthless". (ABC News: Madeleine Rojahn)

Review should be 'embraced', premier says

Mr Rockliff said his government's plan aimed to "ensure community sentiment and confidence increased in the industry".

"This is not something the industry should fear. It's actually something the industry should embrace," Mr Rockliff said.

" Embrace the fact that we are wanting to support the industry become better. "

Jeremy Rockliff says salmon farming has a "positive future" in Tasmania, despite the review. (ABC News: Mackenzie Heard)

He said his government believed the industry had a "positive future" in Tasmania.

Tasmanian salmon industry wants fast-track approval for antibiotic Photo shows Atlantic salmon swimming in an underwater pen. The Tasmanian salmon industry is hoping to get approval within weeks to use another antibiotic to treat farmed salmon, as it continues to grapple with an endemic bacterial disease.

"But we need to continually learn, and we have based our salmon policy over the course of the last decade on continuous improvement."

Labor has not backed the moratorium or review, with Primary Industries spokesperson Janie Finlay criticising Mr Rockliff for another policy backflip.

"[The] salmon announcement isn't about good governance or environmental protection — it's about one man saying anything to cling to power," she said.

"Great Tasmanians, good Tasmanians that are working hard for our economy, working hard for our state, working hard for their families and their communities have been completely tossed aside."

Janie Finlay says the salmon farming review shows the premier is "saying anything to cling to power". (ABC News: Bec Pridham)

This reaction by Labor was deemed reasonable by Greens leader Rosalie Woodruff, whose party, with five elected crossbench members, holds the balance of power.

"That's fair, but what is Labor going to do? What is a genuine trustworthy announcement from Labor to clean up fish farming?"

'Pause' doesn't go far enough

The Bob Brown Foundation's Alistair Allan urged that an "unequivocal commitment" was needed to remove fish farms from Tasmanian waterways.

Mr Allan said the review was a "cynical ploy that does nothing to protect Tasmania's environment from the environmental nightmare that is fish farms" — and Tasmanians had seen an industry "pause" before.

"In 2021 [Liberal MP] Guy Barnett announced a pause, [and then] 12 months later the expansion continues," he said.

Alistair Allan says similar pauses have taken place in the past, with little benefit for Tasmania's marine environment. (Supplied: Bob Brown Foundation)

Mr Allan also cited a 2022 parliamentary inquiry report that recommended a pause on expansion and a reduction of inshore finfish farms, with priority given to "ceasing operations in sensitive, sheltered and biodiverse areas".

"This announcement does nothing to address that," Mr Allan said.

Loading...

Independent MP Peter George, along with Independent MP Craig Garland, proposed the moratorium, and said he was still seeking more details on Mr Rockliff's plan.

"What we can't afford to do is have a pause, have an inquiry, and then have the government totally ignore it. We need to get some undertakings that this inquiry will be treated seriously and its recommendations acted on."

Mr George was asked to respond to workers upset at being used as "a political tool" in Tasmania's minority government, made up of largely progressive crossbenchers.

Peter George wants to ensure the government doesn't "totally ignore" the findings and recommendations from the inquiry. (ABC News: Sophie Jaggers)

He said he did not want to see jobs threatened.

"Workers are being made a political football not by people who want to rein in the damage that the fish farm industry does to our waterways," he said.

"Their fears have been increased by the salmon companies in their political effort to continue to increase their profit. It is the multinationals, that have driven the fear."

title: Snow fleet helps paramedics treat injured patients on the slopes
text:
As skiers and snowboarders make their way up the snow-covered mountains at Perisher Valley, a nearby team of paramedics keeps a watchful eye.

Not far from the Front Valley sits a NSW Ambulance station surrounded by snow.

In the distance, a skier is spotted taking a tumble.

They get back up and dust off the snow before continuing down the slope.

It's a reminder of how dangerous ski fields can be.

Several injuries and, tragically, one death, have been reported on the slopes this winter.

"We're up over 90 incidents, both within the resort and back country jobs," said Mark Gibbs, NSW Ambulance's associate director of southern sector.

He said the start to the season was probably one of the busiest.

NSW Ambulance at Perisher Valley responds to about 200 incidents over a winter season. (ABC South East NSW: Floss Adams)

There has been a dedicated, seasonal team of paramedics based at Perisher Valley since 1986, and for good reason too.

They respond to an average of 200 jobs each winter.

This year, about 20 paramedics have worked in rotation at Perisher, with eight days on, six days off.

Most typically work from 8am to 6pm, but they remain on call in case there are jobs overnight.

The ambulance station at Perisher opened in 1986. (Supplied: NSW Ambulance)

Those stationed on the mountain live in a share-house together but can go home on their days off.

Some paramedics are working here the full three months, others a few weeks.

It's a sought-after assignment.

"It's a very, very selective process, and very competitive. There's lots of staff that are looking to come here," Mr Gibbs said.

"That's why we have quite a stringent assessment to identify the right people with the right skill set."

Mark Gibbs says there is a tough selection process for paramedics who are stationed in the alps. (ABC South East NSW: Floss Adams)

Life on the ice

Some paramedics here have 25 years of experience working in the alps, but there are some fresh faces too.

Trainee Charles Milne, 31, has been a paramedic for 10 years.

Charles Milne says the snow is a challenging environment for treating patients in. (ABC South East NSW: Floss Adams)

He's normally based in Wagga Wagga, but is working in the snow for the first time.

"The medicine remains the same, but we have to adapt it to a challenging environment," he said.

" We're dealing with patients that are cold, patients that are fatigued, and obviously the weather. "

Paramedics respond to a range of incidents including broken legs, heart attacks and collisions between skiers. (ABC South East NSW: Floss Adams)

Mr Milne is not fully out of his comfort zone in the alps, given he's an experienced snowboarder.

But he underwent an extensive induction process to prepare himself for the job, including back country training, avalanche training as well as specialist over-snow vehicle training.

The team at Perisher have just received four new snowmobiles to replace older models and they have been integral to accessing injured patients quickly.

"The snowmobiles allow our teams to get to the patients in, like a rapid responder, like a motorbike," Mr Gibbs said.

"It's to get to the patients in a timely manner."

The Perisher Ambulance Station has received four new snow mobiles. (ABC South East NSW: Adriane Reardon)

Vital fleet

Along with the four snowmobiles, paramedics also have access to two 4WD vehicles, and two larger over-snow vehicles.

One is a snowcat, also known as The Kassbohrer, while the other, The Hagglund, is an all-terrain carrier on lease from Antarctica.

The fleet is vital to accessing not only the main slopes, but the back country too.

The Hagglund (pictured) and The Kassbohrer are used by paramedics to transport patients in the snow. (ABC South East NSW: Floss Adams)

"One of my first cases was a gentleman that had injured himself cross-country skiing up near Porcupine Rocks," Mr Milne said.

"The first responders went out on the snowmobiles, reached the patient and then determined that we were going to bring them back in the over-snow vehicle.

"We see a lot of fractured legs, a lot of fractured arms … as well as heart attacks and strokes.

"Broken legs is probably the thing we've seen the most this week.

" The snow can be dangerous at times. "

Charles Milne has adapted to work life in the snow. (ABC South East NSW: Floss Adams)

Amid the challenges of the job, the paramedics are finding the reward in helping others.

"When family members meet us at the bottom of the hill or as we're loading into the ambulance, there's lots of thanks," Mr Milne said.

"Up here, people are on holidays, so it's that added stress for them.

"When we're able to take that stress away and tell them that their relative is going to be OK and that we're going to get them off to the care they need, that's hugely beneficial."

Paramedics say the job is challenging and rewarding. (ABC South East NSW: Floss Adams)

title: Live: Summit to inform 'next three budgets', Chalmers says
text:
Australian Council of Social Service Cassandra Golding says fixing Australia's "broken" employment services system will be a top priority for her organisation at the economic round table.

Golding says the sector has become "punitive, compliance-driven and damaging to people".

She points out that 1 in 8 Australians are living in poverty, and about half the adult population is living on less than $70,000 per year.

"We want to see the fixing of the employment services system as its [the government's] term two ambition," Golding says. "I think employers know it's not helping them to be able to find the workers that they desperately need, and it's certainly not helping people who are trying to get jobs," she says.

Golding has also called for reforms to social security to reduce the complexity of the system and reduce the number of reports the not-for-profit sector has to complete.

Asked about leaked Treasury documents recommending the government freeze the National Construction Code to boost housing construction, Golding says it's not something she supports.

"The last thing that we should be doing now is freezing the national code. We need to make sure that we've got the right regulations so that every housing footprint that we create now is to standard," she says.

title: Why AFLW stars and experts think this superdraft is going to 'change the game'
text:
Sydney co-captain Chloe Molloy says "the talent is insane" in the new crop of AFLW players who have debuted over the weekend.

The young guns are already being predicted to be a superdraft.

"I think they're going to come in and change the game for how we once knew it to be," Molloy told ABC Sport.

"They take it to another level, which is so exciting for the growth of W."

Molloy back with a bang for Swans in AFLW Photo shows Sydney Swans AFLW star Chloe Molloy bends over, yells and pumps her fists in celebration after a goal. Sydney Swans begin their AFLW campaign with a spirited win over Richmond thanks to starring performances from Chloe Molloy and debutant Zippy Fish.

The 26-year-old Swans star had four goals in her return game from an ACL against Richmond at North Sydney Oval on Friday night.

Joining her in the spotlight was 18-year-old teammate Zippy Fish, who finished with 26 disposals, equalling the most disposals on debut with former league best and fairest Bri Davey.

Fish, taken with pick five in last year's draft, was among a slew of first-year players who exploded onto the scene in round one of the 10th season.

Lucia Painter had three goals for West Coast, while fellow first gamers Ash Centra (Collingwood), Grace Belloni (Essendon), Zoe Besanko (St Kilda), Holly Ridewood (Essendon), India Rasheed (Adelaide), Havana Harris (Gold Coast) and Poppy Scholz (Carlton) all kicked majors in their respective games.

Lucia Painter of the Eagles had three goals on debut. (Getty: Daniel Carson/AFL Photos)

Women's football pioneer Chyloe Kurdas said the AFLW community all agreed last year's was a jumbo draft crop.

"It's no different to the Chris Judd draft crew [known as the superdraft] that we saw all those years ago. Everyone was like, 'Oh my God, that was a bumper draft.' I think we have the same here," Kurdas told ABC Sport.

"It's a very good group of players but I think it's an indication that the deeper investment that has been put into the pathways is working.

Number two draft pick Havana Harris was one of the best on ground for Gold Coast in her debut game. (Getty: Daniel Carson/AFL Photos)

"The players are really well prepared. They've just slotted in really comfortably [and] haven't missed a beat.

"If you look at any of the kids that played on the weekend, especially the top-five picks, in any other draft [they] could've gone number one. So it's a wonderful group of players. We're very lucky."

In one of the biggest developments for AFLW talent, players now entering the system have not had interrupted pathways like the inaugural players, who had to stop playing between the ages of 12 and 18.

Similar to how Harley Reid, Nick Daicos and Will and Levi Ashcroft slotted straight into their respective teams, Kurdas said the high draft picks in the women's game were easing into senior football a lot easier than previous drafts.

"The under-18 system understands what's required at senior level and I think there's greater synergy, or more specific preparation now, for those players, too," Kurdas said.

"The other thing is these players have had a lifetime growing up watching AFLW. So, they've got a really good understanding of the standard that's required of them as they've grown up with the competition being present.

"Whereas your Darcy Vescios [Carlton inaugural player] never had a benchmark to aspire to because there wasn't a competition before them."

Veteran commentator Kelli Underwood said on the broadcast for the Sydney Richmond clash that she felt for the Rising Star selection committee, which had its work cut out for it.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

Kate McCarthy, who has been added to the All Australian selection panel this year, said selecting a Rising Star this season might be just as difficult, if not more, than the All Australian team.

"That's if the first round is anything to go by," McCarthy told ABC Sport.

"The most impressive element of these debutants is that they are competing against a number of girls who have played for nine years and they are holding their own. This is against bodies who have been in an AFLW system for nine preseasons.

"These debutants are girls who have had a footy in their hands their entire life. They have the ball on a string and have played their whole lives. It's so incredibly exciting."

title: NSW learner drivers waiting months to sit their tests
text:
Learner drivers in New South Wales are having to wait up to two months to take their driving test and in some cases are struggling to find a booking at all.

Some people travel long distances to regional towns to take their test, forcing local L-platers to go further afield to secure a spot.

Oran Park student Sian Lynch has been ready to take her test for weeks.

"When I logged in and saw all the time slots were taken, I had to wait a good six to eight weeks before I could book in," the 17-year-old said.

Sian Lynch says the lengthy wait had added to her stress. (ABC News: Marcus Stimson)

She said the delay had added to the stress.

" It was a little bit frustrating. It was also very nerve-wracking knowing that if I did fail my test, I would have to wait two months before I could book in again. "

Gerry Rivet has been a driving instructor in south-west Sydney for almost a decade.

"In an area like this in the Macarthur, there is not much public transport, so we are dependent on people being self-sufficient to get to and from work and school," he said.

"In some cases, the apprentices have been threatened with their job because they need to get a licence for work."

Gerry Rivet says booking a driving test has become a lottery. (ABC News: Marcus Stimson)

He said in recent months, finding an available booking for a driving test had been a lottery.

"You could normally book in within a week. When COVID happened, wait times blew out a fair bit, probably a month or month and a half. Now it's roughly a six to eight-week wait which a lot of people aren't expecting," Mr Rivet said.

"People can't get in here so they're going to Mittagong or Goulburn. The Goulburn people can't get in there, so they're travelling out to Wagga and it's a domino effect."

Record number of driving tests amid high demand

Service NSW, which manages the driving test system, said the spike in demand was driven by a policy change requiring Australian citizens and permanent residents holding an overseas licence to pass the Australian driving test within three months.

Service NSW says policy change is behind a spike in demand. (ABC News: Keana Naughton)

About half the overseas drivers fail the test and then try to rebook, adding to demand.

"This change is about ensuring driver are safer on our roads," a Service NSW spokesperson said.

A record 396,000 driving tests were held in NSW last year — a 12 per cent increase on the year before, but it has not been enough to keep pace with demand.

Abdul Al-Sharhani runs a driving school at Woodbine near Campbelltown.

Recently, he has taken to scouring the booking system himself, looking for cancellations for his drivers.

"I've got many drivers who've told me they need a licence to get a job. It changed their life so those things are really needed," he said.

"I am looking forward for the government to resolve this problem as soon as possible."

Driving instructor Abdul Al-Sharhani runs a driving school at Woodbine, near Campbelltown in south-west Sydney. (ABC News: Marcus Stimson)

'Like putting a little Band-Aid on a big axe wound'

Service NSW said an extra 20 testing officers were being recruited on a temporary basis to help clear the backlog.

Some test centres in Sydney, the Central Coast and the Illawarra are offering tests on Saturdays.

Mr Al-Sharhani is not confident the measures will fix the problem.

"With the load we have now, with the people who came, the people who need their licence, I don't think it's enough," he said.

Mr Rivet described the response as "putting a little Band-Aid on a big axe wound".

Year 11 student Celio Romero plans to take his driving test as soon as he turns 17.

He lives in St Andrews and is often reliant on his parents to ferry him to school, TAFE and his apprenticeship as a boilermaker.

"It's really good to get your Ps so you can get to places on your own," he said.

Year 11 student Celio Romero is planning to take his driving test as soon as he turns 17. (ABC News: Marcus Stimson)

"Say you have family members that have their own work. They don't always have time to take you to work and stuff."

He's hoping to take his test at his local Service NSW centre in Gregory Hills, an hour away from his suburb.

"Travelling to a new area, I don't know if there's a roundabout coming up or if it's as busy," he said.

"It would be more difficult."

Service NSW said the current backlog is reaching its peak but it would continue to monitor the situation and plan for future demand.

It is advising learner drivers to shop around.

"While there may be demands on an individual driver test location, there may be availability elsewhere," a spokesperson said.

title: Family renovates century-old chapel, one jar of jam at a time
text:
It's not every day your daughter casually drops, "I bought a church", into a conversation.

Especially when the church has no roof, no windows, and hasn't heard a sermon since 1968.

But that revelation was the moment life took an almighty turn for Helen and Terry Roebig of South East Queensland's Scenic Rim.

Four years, one very muddy midnight move, and hundreds of jars of homemade rosella jam later, the century-old timber chapel rescued by the Roebigs' daughter, Jess, now sits proudly beside its renovated old schoolhouse.

The renovated church and schoolhouse now sit side by side on the hill. (Supplied: Helen Roebig)

It's a sweet reunion more than 100 years in the making.

" It's like the two buildings found each other again," Helen said. "Now they can grow old together on the hill. "

An old school and a forgotten church

The Roebigs, along with their daughter Jess Bickerstaff, run the Vanbery Cottage Host Farm near Mount Alford, just outside Boonah.

The old Tarome schoolhouse has been converted into a guest cottage on the property. (Supplied: Jess Bickerstaff)

The guest cottage — the former Tarome schoolhouse — had already been moved to its current site and renovated.

So when Jess spotted the old Tarome church for sale on Facebook Marketplace for $4,000, and announced that she'd bought it, the Roebigs jumped at the chance to bring it home and install it beside the old school building, despite not having seen it in person.

"They belonged together, Helen said.

" The school and the church were from the same little rural community, so it just felt right. "

After buying the old church, Jess Bickerstaff then had the task of relocating it to its present location at Mt Alford. (Supplied: Helen Roebig/ABC News: Chris Kimball)

The chapel that jam built

Restoring a derelict church isn't cheap, especially one that has spent the past 50 years as a hay shed.

So, Helen and Jess decided to raise funds with what they had — a patch of rosella bushes and a family tradition of jam-making.

"We planted six bushes and made a few jars," Helen said.

They took them to markets and local shops, and sold them through a bush foods website as demand grew.

Helen Roebig says making jam from rosella flowers is a family tradition. (ABC News: Chris Kimball)

"Now we've got 160 bushes, and everything we earned went into the chapel," Helen said.

" We treated ourselves to a coffee at the market once. That was it. "

The Roebigs built their small business from the ground up: hand-picking the rosella buds, de-seeding them, and cooking every batch.

Jess and Daniel Bickerstaff have worked on the church renovation for years. (ABC News: Chris Kimball)

The profits covered timber, trades, windows, fittings and more.

"Between us, we've preserved jams, fruit, and now churches," Helen said.

So, what exactly is a rosella?

Rosellas are a bright red hibiscus flower with a tart, fruity pod used to make everything from jam to cordial and tea.

Popular in Queensland backyards for generations, they're rich in vitamin C and antioxidants.

Rosella jam used to be a staple in many homes back in the day. (ABC News: Chris Kimball)

Helen remembers rosellas being used for bartering on the family farm in Mulgowie, in the Lockyer Valley, where she grew up.

"Everyone had them," she said. "My sisters would peel them and make jam. I was the youngest, so I got out of most of the work."

Jess picked up the tradition years later while living in England, where she loved to forage for berries and experiment with making preserves.

Helen said that so far this season, they had picked more than 400 kilograms of rosellas, which they have turned into jam, syrup, paste, topping, dried flowers and tea.

Even the copper de-seeder tool Terry designed as the rosella business took off is now sold at local markets.

'That history would have been lost'

The church hadn't had a roof since a storm tore it off in the late 60s. Rebuilding it on a windswept hill was no small job, but the Roebigs found help in local builder Shane Goulding.

"When he walked inside and said it was always his dream to restore a chapel, I knew we'd found the right person," Helen said.

The church before and after the renovations. (Supplied: Helen Roebig)

Nothing in the old building was square, so Terry got to work restoring doors and windows, many of which were salvaged from knockdowns and timber recycling outlets.

"When the girls bought the church, I thought, not again," he said. "We'd already restored a house in Brisbane.

" I figured my renovation days were behind me. "

Slowly, piece by piece, the chapel came back to life.

It's taken four years and hundreds of jars of jam to complete the chapel renovations. (Supplied: Jess Bickerstaff)

"Had it not come here, that history would've been lost," Terry said.

"It might've ended up in Brisbane, but it belonged here."

Love story blossoms

Jess had only been dating her then-boyfriend Dan for two weeks when she told him she'd bought a church.

"It didn't scare him off," Helen said.

"A year later, they were engaged, and the next April they got married in it."

Even though the church was still a work in progress, Jess and Dan were married in it. (Supplied: Jess Bickerstaff)

At the time, the building still had no roof. The floor was stained. Guests sat on hay bales.

"But we had 90 people standing inside," Helen said.

" And why not, when you've got your own church? "

A sweet success

The restored chapel now welcomes visitors from across the country and overseas.

Some come for the views, others for a quiet getaway. A few help pick rosellas or just chat over a cuppa.

New season of Shaun Micallef's Eve of Destruction Photo shows Shaun Micallef is holding 2 chairs from an explosion he survived from with a purple background, the title and ABC iview logo. Micallef is back with a new season from Wednesday, August 13 at 8.30pm on ABC TV and ABC iview.

Helen said the decision to share the property was never difficult.

"We had neighbours on both sides for 38 years in Brisbane," she said. "Now, if someone's staying 100 metres away, that's not hard."

As for Terry, he still gets a kick out of watching people discover what they've built.

Terry Roebig says his renovation days are over. (ABC News: Chris Kimball)

"It's pleasing on the eye, and it's something that'll last," he said.

And the jam? There's always more on the way.

"Whatever grows on the trees," Terry said, "they turn into jam."
